entry.title: A Practical Real-Time CTI Widget for SAP Sales Cloud V2
entry.content:
Over the last weeks, I've been working on a CTI widget for SAP Sales Cloud V2 and wanted to share the practical setup I used to get it running in a production-ready way. The goal was simple: receive real-time call events from a telephony system and push them into Sales Cloud without relying on any custom back-end inside the CRM.

A small CAP backend, a WebSocket channel, and a UI5 widget were enough to make this work end-to-end.

Overall Architecture

The widget runs in an iframe inside SAP Sales Cloud. A CAP service on BTP receives call events from the telephony provider and forwards them to the widget via WebSocket. The widget then sends a formatted XML payload back to Sales Cloud using postMessage.

 

CAP Service with WebSocket Support

The backend uses CAP v9 with Websocket enabled so the widget can react immediately to incoming call events.

@protocol: ['websocket', 'odata']
service WidgetService {
  action notifyEvent(
      date : String,
      caller : String,
      isAnonymous : String,
      callee : String,
      event : String,
      direction : String,
      LID : String
  ) returns String;

  event eventNotification : CTIEvent;
}

Event Handler is handling the incoming event and emits it to connected WebSocket clients. 

this.on("notifyEvent", async (req) => {
  const eventData = req.data;
  await this.emit('eventNotification', eventData);
  return 'OK';
});

WebSocket channel is enabled using the @cap-js-community/websocket plugin. Also we configured the xs-app.json file.

{
"websockets": {
    "enabled": true
  }
}

Mapping the CTI Event for Sales Cloud

Sales Cloud expects a specific XML payload.
The widget maps incoming CTI data into that format.

function mapToSapPayload(cti) {
  const ev = (cti.event ?? "").toUpperCase();
  const dir = (cti.direction ?? "").toUpperCase();

  let eventType = dir === "OUTBOUND" ? "OUTBOUND" : "INBOUND";
  let action = "NOTIFY";

  switch (ev) {
    case "CONNECTED":
    case "ANSWERED":
      action = "ACCEPT";
      break;
    case "ENDED":
      action = "END";
      eventType = "UPDATEACTIVITY";
      break;
  }

  return {
    Type: "CALL",
    EventType: eventType,
    Action: action,
    ANI: cti.caller || "",
    ExternalReferenceID: cti.LID
  };
}

Sending the Event to Sales Cloud (postMessage)

The widget sends the XML using a postMessage call. After that, SAP Sales Cloud receives it and Desktop Agent creating a new live Interaction. See more in @lloyd_goveia 's post called 'How Can You Simplify SAP Service Cloud CTI Integration Testing? Try This Dynamic POC Widget!'.

const xml = jsonToXml(sapPayload);
window.parent.postMessage(xml, "*");

Here is an example payload. See more in SAP Help Portal.

<payload>
  <Type>CALL</Type>
  <EventType>INBOUND</EventType>
  <Action>NOTIFY</Action>
  <ANI>+123456789</ANI>
  <ExternalReferenceID>CALL123</ExternalReferenceID>
</payload>

SAP Sales Cloud reads sent mesagge only if CTI is enabled for the tenant, follow the SAP Help Portal doc for more detail. 

Security Notes

The SAP Sales Cloud domain was added to the App Router allowlist (whitelist) to ensure that SAP Cloud is able to load the widget in an iframe. we need to configure the whitelistService propery in xs-app.json.

{
  "whitelistService": {
    "endpoint": "/whitelist/service"
  },
  "responseHeaders": [
    {
      "name": "Content-Security-Policy",
      "value": "frame-ancestors https://*.crm.cloud.sap"
    }
  ],
  "routes": [
    {
      "source": "^/whitelist/service$",
      "localDir": ".",
      "authenticationType": "none",
      "cacheControl": "no-cache, no-store, must-revalidate"
    }
}

For more information, please visit @sap/approuter in npmjs.com.

Configure SAP Sales Cloud CTI Configuration

There are a few CTI settings that need to be enable first to make the widget show up inside SAP Sales Cloud V2. 

  • Enable CTI Integration --> See SAP Help Portal
  • Register the Widget --> See SAP Help Portal 

Source Code 

The base code is available on Github as a public repo.

Repository Name: gizemsoylutr/sales-cloud-cti-widget

entry.title: From MCQs to Real Skills: My Experience with SAP’s New Certification Format
entry.content:
What Exactly has changed ?

SAP is gradually moving selected certifications away from multiple-choice questions to a scenario-based, practical, hands-on evaluation model.

Instead of selecting the right choice in a MCQ pattern, you now :

  • Configure or Build something
  • Work on real scenarios
  • Receive a defined input and produce an output that is automatically validated against the expected outcome
  • Submit the output 
  • Get evaluated automatically through AI-driven checks

 

Why I personally liked the format 

✔️It rewards real experience 

✔️No more memorizing dumps 

✔️Open-book = Realistic 

✔️Dumps are meaningless now 

 

Who will benefit from this change ?

  • Experienced professionals 
  • New learners 
  • Employers 
  • SAP ecosystem 

 

Which certifications supports this New Format ?

SAP has rolled out the practical, scenario-based exam to six certifications:

Certification Portfolio with Practical Exam 

 

Tips If You're Preparing for This New Exam

  • Practice hands-on tasks 
  • Build small end-to-end examples 
  • Use SAP Help effectively 
  • Focus on solving problems, not memorizing 
 

Conclusion

This new certification format is a huge step forward. It is fair, practical, and aligned with modern SAP project work. Focus on practice, not memory.

entry.title: Introducing User-Defined Reports (UDR) in SAP Responsible Production and Design
entry.content:
Disclaimer: This blog post reflects the state of SAP Responsible Design and Production (RDP) as of November 25, 2025.

SAP Responsible Design and Production (RDP) released User-Defined Reports (UDR) this year, extending its reporting framework with a fully configurable, customer-driven approach developed to support customers with the ever-evolving and growing number of Extended Producer Responsibility (EPR) regulations. With UDR, users can now create customized EPR reports for packaging based on their unique business and compliance needs.

UDR also enables SAP and in the near future, content partners, to offer templates for new EPR schemes that customers can adapt in their own systems, to help them expand EPR reporting quickly. This new functionality aims to ease the burden of managing reporting obligations across multiple markets.

This blog post explains the background and motivation for this feature, provides a sneak peek into the key functionalities used to create country-specific EPR report categories, and highlights how this enhancement improves flexibility and extensibility for EPR data reporting.

Background

As EPR regulations continue to expand globally, businesses face increasing complexity in how they manage compliance. Regulations vary not only from country to country but often overlap or undergo changes over time, making it challenging for customers to keep up while relying on predefined reporting structures.

SAP RDP has long supported customers in meeting EPR requirements through SAP-provided report categories that are preconfigured to match the packaging obligations in countries such as Spain, Italy, and the UK. While these reports have served as a reliable foundation, there is a growing need for a more flexible and more nuanced reporting approach.

Companies increasingly require a way to:

  • Adapt quickly to new or changing legislation
  • Reuse rules and fee structures across similar reporting schemes or Producer Responsibility Organizations (PROs)
  • Consolidate data from diverse sources
  • Customize reporting logic based on their specific business context

This is exactly why SAP introduced User-Defined Reports (UDR): to provide customers with an agile, scalable, and future-ready foundation for building report categories aligned with regulatory logic, business context, and compliance requirements.

Key Capabilities of UDR

User-Defined Reports bring together several powerful capabilities that allow customers to design report categories tailored to their specific regulatory and operational needs. 

1 Build the Structure of Your Report

Responsible Organizations

EPR schemes are managed by Producer Responsibility Organizations (PROs). Many countries operate with more than one PRO, each offering different fee structures or criteria. In Spain, for example, Ecoembes manages general packaging, while Ecovidrio is responsible for glass packaging. UDR allows users to:

  • Attach multiple PRO-specific fee tables to the same report category
  • Reuse the same report fractions and rules across PROs
  • Avoid creating separate report categories for each PRO (as long as their rules do not conflict)

This gives customers flexibility in markets where several PROs coexist.

Report Fractions

Report fractions are the foundational building blocks of a UDR report. They represent the categories into which packaging is classified according to national legislation or PRO requirements. Fractions can be created and named based on the exact fee structure of the country or PRO, ensuring a one-to-one alignment with how fees are calculated.

Report Fraction Groups

To support cleaner structuring and reporting layouts, fractions can be combined into report fraction groups. These groups help users organize related fractions (for example, separating paper-related fractions based on usage or the brand) and simplify both calculation and reporting outputs.

2 Control the Logic Behind Your Report

Filters for Included Packaging

Filters add a foundational layer of control by allowing users to exclude packaging that should not be part of a particular report or fee calculation. They can be applied at multiple levels within the report category setup and help ensure that only relevant data is included based on the requirements of each EPR scheme.

Together with calculation rules, filters help shape a reporting outcome that aligns with legislative and business requirements.

Calculation Rules

Report calculation rules form one of the most powerful elements of UDR.
They determine which packaging is included in a report and how quantities and fees are calculated, giving customers the flexibility to reflect the exact compliance logic required by each market. Because calculation rules can combine multiple conditions, attributes, and data sources, they enable users to shape reporting logic precisely around their business and regulatory needs, making this capability central to the flexibility that UDR offers.

Calculation rules come with a wide collection of rule examples, expressions and functions that can be leveraged to fit the users’ reporting requirements.

Logistic Processes

Logistic processes represent the specific movements of products or packaging that are relevant for a country’s EPR legislation, such as domestic sales, imports, exports, or other flows defined by the market. In UDR, users can select which logistic processes apply to their report category and combine them with filters or calculation rules. This allows the user to reflect only the movements that are obligated in that country, ensuring the report aligns with how packaging enters or leaves the market.

 

3 Capture Sustainability-Driven Criteria

Ecomodulation

Many EPR schemes increasingly use ecomodulation to reward sustainable packaging choices. UDR allows users to set ecomodulation criteria based on the relevant EPR scheme and incorporate them into calculation rules. This further enables fees to be calculated according to the required ecomodulation rules. To learn more about ecomodulation, visit the SAP RDP community page for a detailed blog on this topic, releasing soon.

Recyclability

UDR also integrates recyclability outcomes directly into reports. When setting up a report, recyclability guidelines can be selected and applied, to be used in calculation rules when needed. This allows recyclability insights to feed directly into the report structure, supporting countries where recyclability affects fees or criteria (such as the bonus/malus payments on EPR fees in France). Users can either upload date manually via Excel or integrate with a partner of their choice.

4 Test and Validate Your Setup

Test Configuration

With test configurations, users can simulate the reporting outcome for one to ten products. This enables quick validation of rule logic, filters, and fee calculations before generating the full report, ensuring accuracy and reducing iteration time.

5 Templates

Not all EPR schemes have the same level of complexity. To ease the effort in building highly detailed report categories using UDR, Templates have been introduced; preconfigured starter packs that provide the structure and logic needed to get started, which can be adapted to fit the user’s requirements.

Currently, SAP provides Templates for US-Colorado, US-Oregon, and Denmark, with more to follow. Keep an eye on the SAP RDP Roadmap for upcoming additions.

Customer Response & Early Results

Customers who tested UDR shared strong and practical feedback, including:

“Only 25% of time and effort is required for using UDR compared to manual efforts.” (from consumer products company)

“First we were skeptic, but now we like using UDR.” (from food processing company)

These early insights reflect the impact of a flexible, user-driven reporting approach. To see this in a real-world setting, please check out our recent webinar, Navigating EPR regulations in the United States: Act Now! where our customer shares their experience with UDR.

What’s Next

UDR was shaped with direct input from customers, and this collaboration will continue. As EPR regulations evolve, SAP will focus on enhancing UDR, improving the configuration experience, and supporting reporting needs across markets.

One of the planned enhancements is around AI-assisted features that could make it easier to create calculation rules logic and work more efficiently with UDR using natural language.

Where to Learn More and Act!

To further explore UDR, detailed documentation with practical examples and additional guidance on calculation rules  available. You can also access a guided, step-by-step walkthrough showing how to create a UDR here.  We will continue to publish updates there as UDR evolves.

For broader product information on SAP Responsible Design and Production, we recommend browsing the SAP Help Portal. For an overview of all new features and functions, check the What’s New section, which is updated with every new software release. 

To take the next step, you can request a demo or contact us for a consultation. For additional regulatory context and practical guidance, you may also want to download our white paper on managing EPR regulations and plastic taxes.

entry.title: SAP系统的ETL工具总结
entry.content:
SAP在历史不同阶段推出过不同的ETL工具，用来同步数据

您可能听说过SLT，BODS，Data services，Datasphere，SDI，SDA，RTR这些名词，这里做一个简要汇总解释：

 

1. SAP Landscape Transformation Replication Server (SLT)

是一个需要独立部署的ETL工具，主要用于SAP系统之间的数据同步场景

SLT支持的非ABAP数据源：https://me.sap.com/notes/1768805

SLT支持的非ABAP数据目的地：https://me.sap.com/notes/2737003

 

2. SAP Data Services(BODS)

是一个需要独立部署的ETL工具，主要用于主流系统间的复杂同步场景

BODS支持的数据源和数据目的地列表查询方式：https://me.sap.com/notes/1191469

 

3. Datasphere

Datasphere是一个集成了数据建模和ETL能力的产品，提供两种ETL工具：

3.1 数据流Data flow

是Datasphere内置的ETL工具，主要用于将数据导入Datasphere

3.2 复制流Replication flow

也是Datasphere内置的ETL工具，但其主要用于作为独立ETL对接任意数据源和任意数据目的地

 

Datasphere支持的数据源和数据目的地列表：

https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_DATASPHERE/be5967d099974c69b77f4549425ca4c0/94562426f30c475286f50a1e2b45e743.html

 

4. SAP HANA专用的数据集成工具：

4.1 Smart Data Integration(SDI)

是HANA内置的ETL工具，主要用于将数据导入HANA（有时需要独立部署DP Agent）

SDI支持的数据源列表：
https://help.sap.com/docs/HANA_SMART_DATA_INTEGRATION/7952ef28a6914997abc01745fef1b607/6ed502701abd4d1ca94d463d7dc6e99f.html

SDI常见问题FAQ：

https://me.sap.com/notes/2400022

 

4.2 Smart Data Access(SDA)

是HANA内置的集成模式，主要用于让HANA可以在数据不导入的前提下远程使用数据，实现后HANA用户几乎可以直接把远程数据当作本地表使用（HANA Cloud支持更多云数据源例如Snowflake）

SDA支持的数据源列表：

https://me.sap.com/notes/2600176

 

4.3 Remote table replication(RTR)

是HANA Cloud内置的功能，用于从 HANA Cloud或HANA 向 HANA Cloud同实时步数据

 

以上三种HANA专用功能的练习：

https://developers.sap.com/mission.hana-cloud-extend-on-premise.html

entry.title: The 'Version 1.0' Mindset that keeps me, my mentees, and the BTP teams Upskilling
entry.content:
In my previous blog, I wrote about why people come before process and technology in the SAP BTP journey, or any other transformation project. Once you accept that truth, the next challenge appears almost immediately: how to keep people and their skills up to date, and how to motivate them to stay up to date? In this fast-paced world, technology is constantly evolving. Look at TechEd announcements - SAP RPT-1, SAP BDC connect, AI Agents and MCP servers... the list goes on and on... What do we do? The learning goal is a moving target; you come to a point, and then the goal changes... this is the new normal. And let's be honest, motivation in these situations becomes the biggest hurdle. Everyone knows upskilling is important. Everyone agrees BTP is evolving fast. But finding energy to stay updated? That's where reality hits! And this is where I want to share something personal....

How do I Keep Myself Motivated?

Just like we expect the team to be in a continuous learning mode, we need to hold ourselves accountable, too. And the way I do that is slightly unusual, but effective (at least as of now).

Now and then, I look in the mirror and remind myself:

"Mirror mirror on the wall, I'm still version 1.0 after all."

It's my version of saying I'm not the finished version of myself yet. I'm not the expert; there is always more to learn, more to explore and more gaps to fill. And ultimately, it's a reminder to stay humble, stay hungry and not get too comfortable with what I already know.

This idea is not new; it comes from someone who inspired me a lot while I was working with HCL Tech - Vineet Nayar, former CEO of HCL Technologies. In his book 'Employees First, Customers Second', he talks about the transformation phase he led at HCL Tech. The phase was called 'Mirror, Mirror: Confronting the Truth'. He encouraged the teams to be brutally honest about where they stood, so they could clearly see where they needed to go.

Employees First, Customers Second by Vineet Nayar

So, when I talk about upskilling the team, or the mentees, I start with myself. I have my mirror moments as well, and I need to fill those gaps. Just like I do individually, a few of my mentees are also following the same trick, and they say it works. I believe teams also need their own mirror moment. A space where they can openly acknowledge: We don't know this yet, we are not confident about this service....

There is no shame in that. It's the healthy sign of a learning culture. The only difference I see from individually practising the trick to the teams is the goals, the moving targets. Individuals target as per their choice, needs, and their vision of their own future self, while teams can follow a collaborative approach where we fill the gaps in the team, rather than filling gaps individually. Let's be honest, one person cannot do it all! Team members need to complement each other.

But philosophy is good, what about practicality?

We always want things to happen, and we work towards them. Here is what I propose for teams, from an experience I have gained by practising myself and what I have heard from my mentees:

1. Start by defining the current state and the moving goal.

The mirror exercise - who are you today, what do you want to achieve? But this is an individual version. As a team, what we want to achieve should be the focus.

2. Identify team members and work towards upskilling in a way that complements the team. How do we do that?

One team member cannot be solely responsible for R&D; it should be a shared responsibility. That's how you complement the team.

3. Plan your learning.

Block calendars for learning. There is no alternative. Work will keep you busy every time. Take out time, upskill. Daily/Weekly micro-learning helps initially, and then ramps up based on interest and the subject

4. Frequent check-ins

Keep doing mirror exercise frequently to evaluate what you have or the team has achieved and what is left. Frequency could be monthly if you are on a weekly micro-learning plan, or weekly if on a daily micro-learning plan.

5. Share out as a team

Build PoCs, share with the wider team. This gives you visibility, builds confidence, and motivates others, ultimately helping organisations in the long run.

Do not chase perfection, chase progress. There is one lesson I have learnt in this fast-changing tech stack is nobody knows everything, but everyone can learn something every week/day. Small steps beat big, unrealistic goals. Small wins beat grand transformations. Small continuous upgrades beat occasional 'reactive learning'.

All this starts with the mirror, individually and collectively.

Your Mirror Moment?

What's one skill gap you've been avoiding? What's one thing you're 'version 1.0' on? Share this with your team - not as a confession, but as an invitation, so they feel comfortable sharing their 'version 1.0s'. Please feel free to share how you/your team are coping with the tech stack change and how you are upskilling.

entry.title: Using CAP = Custom Services for SAP Sales & Service Cloud v2 + ESM
entry.content:
In today’s digital landscape, businesses need flexibility to extend standard solutions with custom logic and services. SAP Sales & Service Cloud v2 provides this capability through Custom Services, and the SAP Cloud Application Programming Model (CAP) makes it easier to build and deploy these services on SAP Business Technology Platform (BTP).

This blog walks you through 9 essential steps to create and integrate custom services for SAP Sales & Service Cloud v2 + ESM.

High Level Process flow for designing Custom Services

Step 1 :  Prepare CAP development to your Business Need

Based on the customer business requirements, you can design, develop the CAP service model.. 

Kindly refer Supported and Unsupported functionalities for Custom Services.

Step 2: Deploy to BTP

once the BTP deployment is successful, ensure your CAP Service is working fine with your credentials and test it out with CRUD methods are functional.

Step 3 : Create a Communication System

In SAP Sales & Service Cloud v2 + ESM, create a communication system to connect with your CAP deployed service:

  • Navigate to System Settings → Communication Systems.
  • Add a new system and provide:
    • System ID
    • Host URL (your CAP service endpoint deployed in BTP)
    • Authentication details (OAuth or Basic)

Step 4 : Create a Custom Services

You can create up to 30 custom services in total, with the following limits:

  • A maximum of 30 mashup-based custom services.
  • A maximum of 15 entity-based custom services.

Navigate to User Menu - Settings - All Settings - Extensibility - Custom Services

Step 5 : Prepare CAP File Conversion

Run the following command in (your IDE where CAP is developed) the CLI to convert it to JSON: 
cds -2 json <service.cds file path> >output.json
upload the json as shown in the UI

Step 6 : Upload a File Converted

Upload the file converted from above step and upload as shown in below screen

Step 7 : Configure Host with assigning Communication System

Link your CAP service endpoint with the communication system created earlier:

  • Go to Communication Arrangements in SAP Sales & Service Cloud.
  • Assign the communication system and specify the service URL.

Step 8 : Design the App

On the UI View screen, choose  (Create) available on the top-right corner of the screen.

Select the required UI view pattern for your custom service 

Step 9 : Assign the Business Role to the Custom Services

Finally, ensure proper authorization:

  • Navigate to Business Roles in SAP Sales & Service Cloud.
  • Assign your custom service to the relevant role so users can access it.

Search the custom services and assign the Business Role

Finally look of Custom Services (Displayed in Menu  as Workcenter)

 

Best Practices

  • Use OAuth 2.0 for secure communication.
  • Keep CAP services modular for easy maintenance.
  • Test locally before deploying to BTP.

entry.title: New Security Optimization Service for Cloud Identity Services (CQC SOS for CIS)
entry.content:
Security is no longer optional—it’s the backbone of digital trust and business continuity.

The SAP Security Optimization Service (SOS) is designed to analyze, verify, and improve the security of your SAP system by identifying potential security risks and providing recommendations to mitigate these risks within the assessed systems. 

There are many different SAP systems that can be analyzed with an SOS and can be referred from the CQC SOS Infosheet

🌟New in CQC SOS: SAP Cloud Identity Services (CIS)!

What is CQC SOS for SAP Cloud Identity Services (CIS)?

  • SAP Cloud Identity Services are a group of services of SAP Business Technology Platform (SAP BTP), which enable you to integrate identity and access management between systems. 
  • Besides the CQC SOS for SAP BTP, which provides a security assessment of those security-relevant configurations and authorization assignments which are in the responsibility of the customer and focuses on reviewing the platform aspects, a new CQC SOS in the BTP realm is now available:  CQC SOS for CIS. 

The CQC SOS for CIS provides a security assessment structured in the following sections:

  • General Security Status for CIS - e.g. security aspects related to administrator user/system management like critical authorizations and MFA enforcement, the security alert and notification configuration etc.
  • Security Checks for Identity Authentication - e.g. application specific checks like assigned password policy, MFA,   Remember Me functionality etc.
  • Security Checks for Identity Provisioning - e.g. source and target system settings like logging and tracing for personal   and sensitive data, SSL Server Certificate Verification etc. 

📩How to request a CQC service?

Create an incident under component SV-BO-REQ (SAP Note 1296527) or

Contact the SAP Enterprise Support Advisory team via our Customer Interaction Center (CIC)

☁️As an SAP Enterprise Support or cloud customer:

Make use of the security and the enablement offerings provided by the SAP Enterprise Support Academy.

For more information on the topics discussed in this blog visit SAP Help Portal | SAP Online Help , Identity Authentication , Identity Provisioning

entry.title: Handling High-Frequency message Integration in SAP CPI with SFTP Append Mode Issues
entry.content:
Introduction

Recently we worked on a high-frequency interface using SAP Cloud Integration (CPI) to process a continuous stream of IDocs from a source system. The requirement was to map these IDocs, and send the mapped content to a target system using SFTP. All messages needed to be appended to a single file, and that file was picked up and processed by a job every 5 minutes at the target side.

At first glance, this looked like a simple scenario, but it turned out to be a tricky problem due to the way SFTP receiver works in high-frequency situations.

Problem Statement

We received a high volume of IDocs per minute, and our CPI iFlow was designed to do the following:

Map incoming IDocs to the target structure.

Use the SFTP Receiver Adapter and append to write to a single file for 5 mins after this  the downstream job process every 5 minutes. However, the target system experienced significant problems with increased load.

1. NULL characters in random lines.

2. Truncation of data.

Final file was corrupted or incomplete and therefore unusable. Final file was looking like below:

We noted the following:

The SFTP Adapter in Append Mode cannot support concurrent writes. When multiple CPI threads attempted to append concurrently:

  • Some I/O calls overlapped.
  • File locks failed.
  • The content was corrupted (e.g. NULL characters, partial lines).

CPI does not guarantee ordered or transactional writes when multiple messages are attempting to access the SFTP channel at the same time.

Solution:

To resolve the issue, we redesigned the solution as 2 separate iFlows utilizing Data Store.

iFlow 1 - Message Processing and Write to Data Store

This iFlow receives Idoc from the SAP system and after doing the map it stores the file to the DataStore.

 

Iflow step details:

  • Set header and Content: This is used to set custom header and properties required for processing and logging.
  • Message Mapping: here Idoc structure is mapped to the required target structure.
  • Write: The transformed structure is then write to the Data Store for the next step. This structure should be in XML format for the next step to read it.

iFlow 2 – Aggregation and SFTP File Upload

This iFlow is triggered by a Timer every 5 minutes. It reads all messages stored earlier by the 1st iFlow.

  • We have used Data Store Select to fetch all unprocessed messages in the interval of 5 mins. We have given the number of messages as 500, so that it will pull all the files written by 1st flow on DataStore.

 "Delete on Completion" This check we have selected such that no file will be processed twice after successful processing of the file.

We have given the Number of polled messages as 500, so that it will pick up all the messages that were stored in datastore during last 5 mins. If any data left it will be processed in next poll.

  • When Select step is picking the file up from the data store it combines all the files in the following structure.

In my case the file was looking as below:

We have used a simple groovy to collect all the data between the tag <data> and appended them to create a CSV file

def Message processData(Message message) {
    // Get XML as string
    def body = message.getBody(String)

    // Parse XML using XmlSlurper
    def root = new XmlSlurper().parseText(body)

    // Collect all <data> elements
    def dataLines = root.message.record.data.collect { it.text() }

    // Create CSV string with LF at end
    def csv = dataLines.join("\n") + "\n"

    // Set CSV as new body
    message.setBody(csv)
    return message
}

After the groovy the file looks like as below:

This approach created the file which behaves like Append Mode but in a safe, sequential, and controlled manner.

The resulting content is then sent to the target using the SFTP Receiver Adapter.

In conclusion, this method ensures data integrity, sequential processing, and improved performance by safely simulating append mode of SFTP receiver adapter.
No concurrency issues
No file corruption

entry.title: IFRS 18 Explained: What SAP S/4HANA Customers Need to Know Before 2027
entry.content:
Spoiler
 

IFRS 18 introduces one of the biggest changes to financial statement presentation in decades, replacing IAS 1 and redefining how companies structure their Profit and Loss statements. This blog breaks down the new categories, required subtotals, MPM rules, and cash-flow changes in simple, human language — and explains how SAP is preparing to support customers across S/4HANA Cloud, Private Edition, and On-Premise. With comparative reporting for 2026 and mandatory adoption from 2027, now is the time for finance and IT teams to understand what’s coming and how to prepare their SAP landscape.

What Is IFRS 18 and Why Is It Important?

IFRS 18 is a brand-new reporting standard released by the IASB. It replaces IAS 1 (Presentation of Financial Statements) and becomes effective on January 1, 2027.

In simple terms, IFRS 18 changes how companies present their Income Statement (P&L) and how they explain their financial performance.

Think of it as a cleaner, more structured way to show:

  • Where money comes from
  • Where it goes
  • What part of the business truly drives performance

The goal is to:

  • Make financial statements easier to understand
  • Improve consistency across companies
  • Increase transparency for investors
  • Make comparison between companies more fair and simple

What’s Changing in the Profit and Loss Statement? 

IFRS 18 completely reorganizes the Profit and Loss (P&L) structure.
Instead of mixing items together, companies must now classify every income and expense into new categories:

New Mandatory Categories

  • Operating: Day-to-day business activities
  • Investing: Returns or costs related to long-term investments
  • Financing: Borrowings, interest, and funding-related items
  • Income Tax: All tax-related items
  • Discontinued Operations: Business operations that are shut down or sold

New Required Subtotals

Companies must show these subtotals:

  • Operating Profit
  • Profit or Loss Before Financing and Income Tax
  • Profit or Loss

This improves clarity and avoids situations where different companies calculate “operating profit” differently.

What Are Management-Defined Performance Measures (MPMs)?

IFRS 18 introduces strict rules for something many companies already do:
show custom KPIs like “Adjusted EBITDA,” “Core Profit,” or “Underlying Margin.”

These are called Management-Defined Performance Measures (MPMs).

Under IFRS 18, companies MUST:

  • Explain how the measure is calculated
  • Explain why it is useful
  • Provide a reconciliation to an official IFRS subtotal
  • Include this reconciliation in the notes, and it must be audited

This improves trust and transparency around custom metrics that companies use to tell their story.

Changes to the Cash Flow Statement

IFRS 18 also updates IAS 7 (Cash Flow Statements).
Previously, companies had flexibility in classifying certain cash flows.

Under IFRS 18:

  • Dividends paid → must be shown under Investing activities
  • Interest paid → must be shown under Financing activities
  • Interest received → must be shown under Investing activities

This eliminates the old “choice-based” method and brings global consistency.

Impact on Financial Reporting and Disclosure

IFRS 18 affects several areas of financial reporting:

P&L Structure

Companies must reorganize their charts of accounts and reporting hierarchies.

Disclosures and Notes

More detail is required, especially around MPMs, aggregation rules, and reconciliation.

Comparative Reporting

Mandatory disclosure of 2026 figures in the new IFRS 18 structure when reporting for 2027.

What Does This Mean for Companies Using SAP?

SAP is currently analysing the full impact of IFRS 18 and consulting with customers through Customer Engagement Initiatives.

Key areas SAP is reviewing include:

  • Functional areas
  • General Ledger structure
  • Valuation processes
  • Reporting frameworks in S/4HANA
  • Group Reporting layouts
  • Cash-flow classifications
  • Universal Journal (ACDOCA) extensibility

SAP expects to release a formal solution approach by December 2025(as documented in SAP Note-https://me.sap.com/notes/3670330/E) . This guidance is expected to be included in the IFRS 18 updates for SAP Group Reporting as part of the 1SG content package.

The solution may differ across editions:

  • SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition
    → Expect more standardized, pre-delivered content
  • SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition
    → More flexibility with governance
  • SAP S/4HANA On-Premise
    → Potentially greater configurability

SAP will deliver updates through notes, documentation, and future releases.

How Customers Can Prepare Today

Even before SAP finalizes its solution, companies can begin preparing by:

✔ Reviewing current P&L structures
✔ Identifying where income/expense items will map under IFRS 18
✔ Understanding new disclosure requirements
✔ Reviewing cash-flow classifications
✔ Collecting internal MPM definitions
✔ Engaging with SAP through CEI or Customer Influence Requests

Early preparation will make the transition smoother when IFRS 18 becomes mandatory.

Conclusion

IFRS 18 represents a major shift in how companies communicate their financial performance. The new structure, required subtotals, stricter rules for custom KPIs, and updates to cash flow presentation will significantly impact both finance teams and system configurations.

As outlined in SAP Note 3670330, SAP is developing a comprehensive solution targeted for late 2025, with further updates expected as IFRS 18 continues to evolve. In my view, this is the right time for organizations to start understanding the new requirements, assess their current data and reporting structures, and begin preparing their SAP landscapes for a smooth transition.

More updates will come as SAP refines its roadmap — stay tuned.

Security and the protection of your systems have become more important than ever and play a crucial role in today’s business environment.

  • Provides fine-grained control over On-premises systems and resources that can be accessed by cloud applications and Cloud applications using the Cloud Connector.

The CQC SOS for Cloud Connector provides a security assessment structured in the following sections:

entry.title: How far will AI go... and what will it mean for your job?
entry.content:
In April this year, I decided to voluntarily retire early from SAP after 6 years of a very interesting journey. Indeed, I've lived from the inside the infusion of powerful Artificial Intelligence capabilities in SAP Build, for application development and for process automation.

Since then, I've spent 8 months observing the IT industry evolution, particularly around AI. And now, I have very mixed feelings:

✔️ On one hand, I'm impressed how well SAP is positioned on the market and how SAP AI is powerful

❓ On the other hand, I'm more and more worried by the impact humanoid robots and AI, from SAP and all vendors, will have on so many jobs everywhere.

So I decided to share my views with you in this blog post.

SAP is amazingly well positioned with Business AI

A month ago I watched SAP TechEd Keynote and also a few sessions, and I have to say that I'm impressed. By the way, in case you missed it, watch the replay of the keynote:

I discovered AI more than 40 years ago, when I was studying to graduate in 1986 as an engineer in computing science, and 10 years ago I was working for Antidot, a french startup involved in knowledge graphs, where I wrote this white paper on Business Knowledge Graphs in 2014.

So, from my humble point of view, putting together SAP ERP + SAP Business Data Cloud + SAP Knowledge Graphs + SAP Business AI with Joule creates a winning combo. It puts SAP in a unique position , better than any competitor, to bring the best of AI to the customers.

And what has been presented and announced at SAP TechEd makes SAP even stronger:

SAP-ABAP-1 is a new model allowing to handle ABAP language: trained on more than 250 million lines of ABAP code, 30 million lines of CDS code, and extensive technical documentation, it is purpose-built to explain and generate modern ABAP code.

SAP-RPT-1 (Relational Pre-trained Transformer Model-1) is a brand new classification and regression model, allowing to better handle structured, tabular business data. It is a paradigm shift in machine learning, introducing a revolutionary approach that eliminates the security-performance trade-off entirely. SAP-RPT-1 achieves state-of-the-art performance and already outperforms regular text-based LLMs through semantic understanding of tabular relationships.

Knowledge Graph in SAP HANA Cloud is an RDF graph built from system catalog, capturing tables, columns, relationships, and annotations. It providesthe semantic layer needed for exploration, AI grounding, and graph-based reasoning. It allows agents to reason about data, to understand entities relationships, and which attributes are relevant. 

A2A and MCP protocols foster Agentic AI by allowing autonomous agents collaboration: SAP is providing out-of-the-box Joule agents and alllowing customers to create custom agents with Agent Builder in Joule Studio. Beyond that, agentic protocols such as A2A - Agent to Agent - and MCP - Model Context Protocol - with SAP Lean IX Agent Hub and Agent Mining in SAP Signavio allow to standardize, deploy and monitor AI agents collaboration.

To dig deeper on these topics, follow the links I've put in the text above, watch the replay of the SAP TechEd sessions and also refer to

  • SAP  Innovation Guide
  • SAP Guide "What is Joule?" 

What impact will AI have on human employment?

So, we all agree, SAP is doing very well with Business AI for empowering companies to do better and faster. And this is very good for SAP and its entire ecosystem.

But when it comes to employees working in these companies, things could be different. Indeed, some news popping up in mainstream media are a bit worrying. For instance, according to McKinsey & Company, AI can already do almost 60% of all the work:

Their research “Agents, robots, and us: Skill partnerships in the age of AI” says that the future of work will be basically shaped by partnerships among people, agents, and robots - all powered by AI. The research emphasizes that capturing AI’s massive potential economic value - about $2.9 trillion by 2023 in the US only! - depends entirely on how organizations will reorganize.

Indeed, be it for business users, for consultants, for developers, AI agents will be everywhere... and they will do a lot of tasks done by human employees today.

And we have already seen this year how big tech firms have "reorganized" to embrace AI benefits: 

  • Amazon - 30,000 layoffs
  • Accenture - 11,000 layoffs
  • Microsoft - 6,000 layoffs
  • HP - 4,000-6000 layoffs

So in total more than 50,000 jobs have been erased in a few months only. And SAP as well is shrinking its workforce: “In one year, it could be one or sometimes two percent of jobs that are eliminated” said Christian Klein, and Dominik Asam  added “There are certain tasks which are automated and for the same volume of output we can afford to have less people". He admits to be "brutal",  comparing this program to routines such as brushing teeth...

Meanwhile, it seems everyone is trying to reassure the public that everything will be fine… perhaps to prevent tens of millions of workers from becoming upset about the prospect of losing their jobs?

Should not a part of the value created by all the AI software and humanoid robots be used to compentiate this massive loss of jobs?

Today, in many countries, health insurance, unemployment insurance, and pensions are financed by contributions paid by employers and employees on human work. If the number of employees is decreasing, shouldn't social security contributions be levied on the work performed by AI agents and humanoid robots?

Will robots embrace Karl Marx slogan? 🙃

What do you think? How do you envision the impact AI and robots will have on your job in 3, 5 or 10 years?

Your feedback will be highly appreciated, so feel free to share your own views in the comments!

entry.title: Prompt Engineering: Unlocking Hidden Power for Enterprise AI Success
entry.content:
Gaps in Prompt Design Derail the User Experience

What happens when gaps in prompt design or user intent recognition turns everyday AI interactions into a dead‑end waste of time?

Have you ever experienced this type of situation?

For example, I recently tried to claim a rebate for a kitchen appliance, but the company’s AI assistant misinterpreted my request and left me stuck with irrelevant FAQs. The issue was poor prompt design. With proper prompt engineering, the assistant could have recognized my rebate request and guided me to the correct, enabled form. A smarter workflow would have turned a dead end into a faster way to get my rebate money.

What fun!

This experience underscores a critical truth: when prompts fail to capture real‑world users’ intent, the customer experience collapses.

For business and IT users working with AI, this isn’t just a consumer inconvenience, it’s a wake‑up call. Prompt engineering is more than a technical capability; it’s the discipline of shaping interactions so that AI systems understand nuance, adapt to context, and deliver meaningful results.

Whether in customer service troubleshooting, enterprise workflows (agentic AI), or customer engagement, the quality of prompts directly determines the quality of the user experience.

In this age of AI agents and assistants, refining prompts is no longer optional; it is essential for building trust, driving efficiency, enabling scalable automation, and achieving successful outcomes.

Reducing AI Project Failures - Understanding Prompt Engineering

Prompt engineering is the art and science of designing inputs that guide AI models to produce desired outputs. By framing instructions accurately, organizations can harness AI to generate relevant, high-quality responses.

According to a RAND report, 80% of AI project failures stem from poor human to AI communication. Misunderstandings between business and IT teams about goals, data, and capabilities are the most common cause of failure. Companies that master prompt engineering achieve significantly higher ROI compared to those relying on basic or ad hoc prompting (1).

In short: success doesn’t come from the technology alone; it comes from how we communicate with it.

Why It Matters

Prompt engineering is no longer a fringe capability and skill. It is becoming a critical organizational capability embedded into everyday business functions.

According to Market Research Future (MRFR), the prompt engineering market was valued at $2.195 billion in 2024 and is projected to grow to $32.78 billion by 2035, with a staggering 27.86% CAGR (2).

SAP Prompt Engineering Adoption

Prompt engineering transforms vague queries into precise instructions, guiding AI toward accurate, consistent, and actionable outputs. With AI agents and assistants like SAP’s Joule, Microsoft Copilot, Google Gemini, and OpenAI’s ChatGPT, organizations recognize that prompt engineering is essential to maximize AI’s potential and align outcomes with business goals.

SAP has embedded prompt engineering into Joule, powered by the Generative AI Hub in SAP AI Core and Launchpad (part of the SAP Business Technology Platform) and supported by SAP’s AI Foundation, delivering enterprise‑grade accuracy and trust with Large Language Models (LLMs).

At SAP Sapphire 2025, SAP announced a proprietary Prompt Optimizer built with the company, Not Diamond. This optimizer enables enterprises to migrate and adapt prompts across multiple LLMs, supporting consistency, accelerating adoption, and improving the user experience across diverse AI systems (3).

Not Diamond envisions “a multi‑model AI future, with thousands of foundation models, millions of fine‑tuned variants, and billions of custom inference engines running on top of them.” Their infrastructure routes, governs, and scales prompts across these systems, ensuring flexibility and trust.

This partnership confirms prompt engineering as an important, core enterprise requirement, bridging business strategy with technology capabilities for responsible AI.

Best of Prompt Engineering Capabilities

Prompt engineering serves as the strategic layer that transforms raw AI capabilities into business value, delivering a range of benefits including:

  1. Clarifies Intent – Ensures AI understands user goals, reducing miscommunication and aligning outputs with business needs.
  2. Customer Engagement & Personalization – Crafts prompts that drive tailored chatbot interactions, outreach, and recommendations, fostering loyalty and satisfaction.
  3. Structures Outputs – Guides AI to deliver usable formats (tables, lists, reports, narratives) for clarity and consistency.
  4. Improves Efficiency & Operational Automation – Minimizes unnecessary token usage, accelerates turnaround, and empowers agentic AI to automate repetitive workflows such as reporting, summarization, and FAQ handling.
  5. Adds Domain Context – Embeds industry‑specific language, governance and compliance rules, approved product names, synonyms, and brand tone for relevance.
  6. Supports Scalability Across Teams – Builds reusable prompt libraries and frameworks that allow consistent enterprise‑wide adoption without reinventing workflows.
  7. Content Quality & Consistency – Ensures outputs are brand‑aligned, accurate, and emotionally resonant across all channels.
  8. Optimizes Across Models – With tools like Not Diamond’s Prompt Optimizer, prompts can be migrated and adapted across Copilot, Gemini, ChatGPT, Joule, and other LLMs.
  9. Enhanced Accuracy & Decision‑Making – Produces precise, consistent outputs and extracts actionable intelligence quickly to support better business decisions.

By uniting these capabilities, prompt engineering becomes the foundation for trustworthy, scalable, and business‑aligned AI success.

Short on Time? Who Manages Prompt Engineering

Prompt engineering isn’t just the domain of IT or developers; business roles like product managers, business analysts, marketing, communications, operations, UX/CX designers, content strategists, and other lines of business are equally critical.

For example, product managers align prompts with business goals, analysts map workflows, designers ensure intuitive user experiences, and strategists refine language and tone. Together, they make AI outputs reliable and customer‑centric.

Also, a dedicated, focused part‑time prompt engineering consultant can help jumpstart this process by auditing the current status, delivering best practices, and establishing governance standards in collaboration with IT and key stakeholders.

In a fast paced, short-handed, busy work environment, these prompt optimization specialists can provide support by providing focus and discipline, coaching key stakeholders with standard operation procedures (SOPs), monitoring performance, and refining prompts as business needs evolve to help ensure AI systems remain accurate, consistent, and trusted across the enterprise.

Final Thoughts

Prompt engineering is no longer a niche skill or technical curiosity; it has become a core business capability that drives efficiency, compliance, and innovation. Organizations that embrace it gain a competitive edge, while those that neglect it risk wasted investments and inconsistent results.

By embedding prompt engineering as a business standard, integrated into workflows through enterprise‑wide libraries, governance, and automated refinement, companies can optimize AI strategies to keep pace with evolving models, regulations, and customer expectations.

The future of enterprise AI will not be defined by those who merely explore prompts, but by those who master them, transforming raw model potential into trusted, scalable business value.

And as a result, users can save time by getting answers versus gaps and dead ends.

entry.title: How to Scale AI: The importance of modernizing data and integrating processes
entry.content:
How to Scale AI: The importance of modernizing data and integrating processes

Read the original article here

Expectations of the potential impact of AI have never been higher. But so far, most projects have only produced incremental improvements in isolated areas. So, what do you have to do to get AI to deliver material change across your business? The answer lies in preparing your processes and data—getting them into a condition where AI can use them to deliver on its promise of radical transformation. In this thought provoking article, two AI experts from SAP explain what’s involved, where to get started, and which SAP solutions can help you really put AI to work.

About the authors:

Jürgen Butsmann is part of the SAP Cloud ERP Product Marketing team responsible for AI in the context of SAP S/4HANA, finance and digital supply chain. Jürgen has been with SAP for more than 26 years.  He is a recognized expert for SAP S/4HANA and SAP BTP .

Terry Penner is part of the SAP BTP product marketing team, focused on SAP BTP for Cloud ERP. He has more than 25 years of technical and business experience in the SAP platform and analytics, including working directly on hundreds of customer implementations and presenting on SAP technology topics at conferences around the world.

 

The challenges in reaching AI’s potential

Business leaders believe AI has the potential to transform their organizations.  They see it accelerating cycle times, reducing errors, performing processes automatically, and yielding insights. Their initial experiments and projects have reinforced this expectation by delivering productivity improvements, albeit in isolated areas.

However, return on investment has so far been disappointing and IT teams are finding it challenging to scale AI beyond point solutions. They’re also nervous for ethical and security reasons about exposing their proprietary business data to public large language  models (LLMs).

Observations from customers

The discussions we’ve been having with SAP customers have revealed these common challenges IT leaders face in realizing AI’s potential.

  • Insecure architecture. Using public LLMs alone is not always reliable. AI really needs to use the organization’s own business data. But exposing corporate data to LLMs raises security and ethical issues.
  • Fragmented systems. Applying AI to a process that is contained within a single system is relatively easy. But most real business processes span multiple departments and systems. Often these applications and their data are not integrated which prevents AI from carrying out business processes end to end.
  • No single semantic layer. Enterprise applications today, whether SAP or non-SAP, all have differences in their data structures. Data transformation and harmonization are necessary to allow the sharing of transactional data, and for analytical processes and AI functions to  take place.
  • One-way data transformation. Data warehousing, as practiced by SAP and by other vendors in the past, focused on extraction  and one-way transformation, storage, and processing of data, decoupled from original data structures and business process context. Effective, enterprise-wide AI, however, requires two-way transformation and re-integration of data into business processes as they run.

What organizations need

AI agent networks need a solid data foundation  if they are to process queries across systems effectively. The organization’s data structures—its master data and system architecture—need to be harmonized so AI can understand the different systems in a consistent and accurate way.

When processes are integrated, consistent data can be stored in the systems. Integrating systems and maintaining consistent data will overcome the problem of isolated, fragmented systems and allow AI to execute end-to-end business processes.

 

SAP’s strategy for scalable AI

SAP’s approach to enabling organizations to scale their use of AI is to facilitate the integration of systems and business processes, and the harmonization of business data, within a secure AI architecture.

The key components of this are:

  • Secure AI architecture
  • Solutions for scaling AI
  • Joule, the integrated digital assistant
  • SAP Business Data Cloud (SAP BDC) for data harmonization
  • SAP Business Technology Platform as the platform for Joule, SAP BDC, AI Hub, and process

Secure AI architecture

Figure 1: A common sub-optimal approach

Figure 2: Exposing corporate data to LLMs is not recommended

Figure 3: How to allow AI to understand your business safely

SAP's secure architecture allows AI to understand your business safely.

The process works like this:

  • The user queries their digital assistant, Joule.
  • The digital assistant uses both the LLM and the vector database to create a refined prompt. The technical process is decoupled from the proprietary business data (a technique known as masking) to prevent the data being exposed outside the organization.
  • The refined prompt then requests data from cloud ERP and other proprietary systems, such as the  SAP Foundation Model.
  • Data is returned to the digital assistant via the vector database and the results are clustered and explained by the LLM.
  • The digital assistant then presents the final answer to the user.

 

SAP solutions for scaling AI

As an SAP customer, you may be familiar with our strategic architecture. Working from the top down, we call out here three elements which are material to scaling AI.

Figure 4: SAP strategic architecture

Joule

Joule is SAP’s agent orchestrator and ubiquitous user interface for AI. It is embedded throughout SAP Business Suite solutions incl. SAP Cloud ERP and SAP Cloud ERP Private. Joule skills perform simple repetitive tasks within one application. Joule Agents give context-aware access to a system  of AI agents, that can perform more complex end-to-end processes across multiple systems— provided those systems have been integrated and their data’s been harmonized.

Agents can work within or separately from Joule. They can call and quest other agents in the background without having to be triggered manually. This is done transparently in Joule to keep the human in the loop.

SAP Business Technology Platform

SAP Business Technology Platform supports SAP Business Suite solutions. It provides a foundation for AI and data analytics and includes integration and extension solutions.

  • SAP Integration Suite contains more than 3,800 prebuilt integrations and APIs for connecting business processes across systems more easily.
  • SAP Build solutions help you create extensions and automate processes across SAP and  non-SAP solutions.

SAP Business Data Cloud

SAP Business Data Cloud provides a single semantic layer across applications and enables the harmonization of data. This is essential not only for AI to work effectively, but also to share transactional data and facilitate analytical processes. SAP BDC uses data products which are prebuilt multi-layered structures (which may include extensions of clean-core compliant data structures) for executing function-specific queries and processes across SAP and non-SAP systems.

Having a common data platform across your enterprise allows AI to utilize your proprietary  business data within a secure environment. The data products come as part of so-called intelligent applications which contains applications built using the SAP Cloud Application Programming Model, as well as other domain content.

Customers can always extend the data layer, for example by defining custom data products.

Advantages of SAP Business Data Cloud

In some cases, operational data has been used for executing AI functions or analytical and planning operations without applying data products from SAP BDC. In the past, data storage for these operations took place in BTP, as the AI hub is located there as well as in SAP Datasphere and SAP HANA. But what was missing was the delivery of a common and harmonized data storage concept across all SAP applications.

SAP BDC makes it possible to establish a common architecture where data is extracted, transformed, and returned to SAP Business Suite applications, creating harmonized data storage. A common data platform across your organization will provide the data foundation for AI to connect securely to specialized, enterprise-specific data.

SAP BDC also allows for SAP-managed deployment, maintenance, and facilitation of data processing and transformation from the source system to SAP BDC. These services are part of the data products of the intelligent applications.

SAP Business Suite provides APIs between different SAP and non-SAP applications, allowing the data exchange needed for integrated execution of business processes.

Prioritizing the establishment of a common layer also influences changes to local data structures. The data required to support integrated business process and other cross-system operations is held directly within the source systems, with no need for a secondary harmonization layer. This is very well aligned with the clean core concept.

 

What does it mean for me?

Do I need all this before my AI will work?

No, but the more elements you have, the more value you get.

  • If you only have SAP BDC, you’ll have access to harmonized data—but you won’t yet have connected business processes across applications.
  • If you use SAP BTP solutions such as SAP Integration Suite and SAP Build to create integrations and extensions, you’ll be able to join up business processes across applications—but not harmonize their data.
  • If you use SAP BDC and SAP BTP solutions together, you can integrate business processes across systems and harmonize their data. A derived harmonization model is intended to be generated by the system using APIs to produce a fully integrated model for cross-system reporting and AI data usage. Then Joule Agents can use that harmonized data to orchestrate end-to-end business processes across multiple systems automatically.

Are there other ways of doing this?

Yes, but they’re not as good. Some of our customers use third party data harmonization solutions for cross-system analytical use cases.

The difference with SAP’s AI-first strategy is that it is always aware of the actual business context and reintegrates results data back into the business process. This is essential if AI agents are to make use of that data in cross-department, cross-system use cases.

SAP’s integrated suite of ERP and business applications, together with our data management solution, and our integration and extension solutions, is unique in the marketplace at present.

How can I move from isolated use cases to enterprise-wide AI?

Basically, you need to offer AI that people can trust.

To achieve trust, you need a secure AI architecture along with integrated processes and harmonized data. When you have these, people will trust the AI model. Then they’ll come to view it as reliable and adopt it for day-to-day, end-to-end business processes across the organization.

 

How this approach can help you - a worked example

Automating financial close

One of the most attractive use cases for AI is to modernize a business process which occurs in every business and which, if automated, would deliver significant productivity and cost benefits. The process in question is the financial close.

It’s a classic challenge. The data required sits in multiple systems, such as ERP, CRM, tax engines, and payroll—which aren’t integrated. The data is also in incompatible formats. Both these mean that considerable manual work is required in extracting and reconciling the data. All of which adds up to time, cost, and stress at the end of every accounting period.

With systems integrated using SAP Integration Suite, and data harmonized using SAP Business Data Cloud, Joule Agents can be built to help perform financial close processes optimally—always leaving knowledgeable human beings to make the final decision.

SAP’s enablers of autonomous finance can expedite financial close processes and deliver material cost savings. The Canadian energy company, Suncor, achieved a reduction of US$20,000 in month-end closing costs and a 98% reduction in time to reconcile ICT postings using SAP Business AI and SAP Build Process Automation.

Figure 5: Integration flow diagram of a connected financial close process in SAP Integration Suite.

 

How do I get started?

To summarize, our two key recommendations are to modernize your data and integrate your processes.

Modernize your data

Evolve your data strategy from using harmonized historical data extracted from business systems, to using current data generated in the process of executing business processes.

Aim to make multiple data sources accessible to AI, including a combination of business data from multiple internal systems and external data.

Integrate your processes

Move away from older integration technologies that are not cloud aware, such as process integration or process orchestration, to standardizing on SAP Integration Suite with thousands of prebuilt integrations.

Adopt a consistent method across the organization for connecting your processes so that when you build AI agents to orchestrate them across multiple systems, users get a consistent experience.

 

Immediate next steps

Ask your SAP account manager to set up a conversation with one of our enterprise architects. You can discuss where you are now, where you want to be, and draw up a plan for getting there.

In the meantime, find out more about:

  • SAP Business Technology Platform
  • SAP Integration Suite and SAP Build
  • SAP Business Data Cloud
  • SAP’s vision for autonomous finance

entry.title: How to verify the Swiss E-ID on the SAP Business Technology Platform
entry.content:
How to verify the Swiss E-ID on the SAP Business Technology Platform

Switzerland is progressing with its new state-operated E-ID, branded swiyu, built on decentralization, privacy-by-design, and open standards. This new solution ensures the privacy design with a system where identity data stays on the user’s device, verification happens peer-to-peer, and the entire infrastructure is publicly governed.
While the official release of the Swiss E-ID is scheduled for summer 2026, the E-ID excites many customers, being the hot topic not only for the public sector in Switzerland but also E-Commerce shops for age checks and customers regulated by the “Know Your Customer” guidelines.

Business Relevance

In recruiting, the identity of a new hire is a key information not only in regulated industries. Some products may only be sold to customers of a certain age or to customers which are identified. Some processes “digitize” the physical ID-Card or Passport using Video, other processes depend on the holder of the ID to show it physically to an agent. As all that is in an ID is data, finding better ways of handling this data should be easy?
However, having a trusted form of identification in the digital era is not as straightforward as one might think. Today, many companies are forced to use external identity validation services including video calls for a Face-to-Face verification. Those services come with high costs and disrupt the smooth user experience for the end consumer.
A trusted digital identification would solve those challenges which the E-ID aims to become. With swiyu, Swiss organizations and citizens will have a compelling solution in their hands – ready for integration in their existing processes. SAP Switzerland wants to help its customers in this process for a simple and seamless integration.

Architecture

For the E-ID verification 3 main components are necessary: the E-ID of the consumer, the webpage where the verification process is presented and the verifier ensuring the authenticity, validity, and trust. The E-ID is stored in the digital wallet (swiyu app) on the personal smartphone of the end user. The generic verifier, an open-source application provided by the swiss government, is hosted by the company initiating the verification process. It ensures the trusted communication with the public government registry using anonymized records of the issued IDs.

What is needed for an implementation?

Knowing how the E-ID verification works in theory is nice but of little use if not used in practice. To have a verification with the E-ID in place the generic verifier application needs to be hosted and publicly accessible. The docker image provided by the government can be used to have it up and running in no time. The company running this verifier then needs to put its trust anker in the government registry to be recognized as a valid verifier. Then the webpage needs to integrate to the generic verifier. This integration allows the generation the QR Code and (once the consumer approved the validation request) receiving the results from the E-ID login.

The steps on how to perform this on SAP Business Technology Platform are outlined below.

Setting Up Your Own Verifier on SAP BTP

Setting up the Generic swiyu Verifier on SAP BTP is straightforward: it involves a registration on the e-portal of the Federal Office of Information Technology, Systems and Telecommunication (FOITT), generating a Decentralized Identifier (DID), and deploying to SAP BTP.

Prerequisites:

  • Cloud foundry space
  • PostgreSQL Entitlement

Register on the swiyu Base & Trust Registry

Before starting the technical setup, you register on the swiyu Base & Trust

  1. Register your business or yourself on the e-portal and save the Business Partner ID for later.
  2. Navigate to the API Self-Service Portal:
    1. In the Applications tab, create a new application.
    2. After creation, select the application and subscribe to the Identifier and Status APIs.
    3. Save the Access Token, Refresh Token, and other credentials for later use.

Create a DID and Identifier Space

  1. Using your Business Partner ID and Access Token, request a DID space on the Identifier Registry. Save the Identifier Registry URL and ID for the next steps.
  2. Clone the swiyu DID Toolbox from GitHub and run it with your Identifier Registry URL to create a new DID.
  3. Save the output. The returned array contains your DID and other verification/authentication details.
  4. Store the entire output as a string in the created Identifier Space using the obtained details.

Optional: To become a trusted participant (i.e., to display the “verified” badge when verifying credentials), register for the Trust Registry. Details can be found on the organizations page in the e-portal.

Deploy the Verifier to SAP BTP

  1. In the BTP Cockpit, start a dedicated PostgreSQL instance. The smallest tier is sufficient as the DB only holds cache data.
  2. After provisioning, create a service key to obtain authentication details for the verifier service.
  3. On your local machine, create a manifest.yml file specifying the name, instance, memory, and environment variables (see documentation).
    • When deploying only with the Docker file, you must host your verifier metadata file separately to allow the service to access it.
  4. Push the application using the Cloud Foundry CLI.

You have now deployed the Generic Verifier to SAP BTP and created an API service for verifying VCs on the swiyu Trust Infrastructure. 

 

Basic architecture of swiyu verifier integrated into SAP BTP

 

 

Accessing and Securing the API

Access your APIs via the built-in Swagger UI at: <your-server-url>/swagger-ui.html
Optionally, secure the management API endpoints using a fixed asymmetric key or an OAuth2.0 Server.
Note: This process is intended for PoC and familiarization purposes. For full production deployment, check out the deployment considerations here.

Optional: Frontend Integration
In our PoC, we also created a frontend service using UI5 and CAP to integrate JWT authentication with the Verifier Service. This makes it easier for users to interact with and test the service.

Verifying credentials

Screenshot of Credential-Check on the swiyu AppThe process of verifying credentials from a wallet begins when the wallet user scans an offer QR code. This QR code must contain a (deep-)link, which you generate through an API call to the management API of your verifier service.
After scanning the QR code, the wallet holder is prompted to either accept or decline the verification request (see figure 1). If the user accepts, the requested details are sent to the verifier service. These verification results can then be retrieved either by polling the service or by receiving them through a webhook callback.

 

 

Conclusion

You have now deployed and configured the generic swiyu verifier on SAP BTP, registered on the swiyu trust registry, created a DID/identifier space, and enabled QR-based credential verification (with an optional UI5/CAP frontend and basic security options).
Based on this, integration in business processes can replace costly external identity checks by enabling seamless, privacy-preserving E-ID verification for recruiting, age checks, KYC flows and other customer-facing processes while keeping identity data on the user’s device and relying on the public trust registry.

In a next step, we will explore how to issue certificates, including creating verifiable credentials, the issuer workflow, required registry entries and production-grade deployment. Stay tuned!

Special Thanks goes to Matthias Beeler for developing the PoC and helping create this Blog post, but also Alex Finger, Michael Kaczalak and Patric Imark for driving the topic!

 

Sources:
https://swiyu-admin-ch.github.io
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Know_your_customer

entry.title: SAP to Collaborate with AWS to bring the SAP BTP ABAP Environment to Arm-Based AWS Graviton
entry.content:
Authors: Steven Jones (AWS), Sonja Liénard (SAP)

The key to SAP’s innovation and adoption success has always been its openness, supporting diverse hardware platforms, networks, and technology ecosystems, while offering flexible deployment options for customers operating in mixed and heterogeneous environments. This principle extends to the ABAP Platform and especially the BTP ABAP Environment, which powers next-generation ABAP Cloud applications and extensions. Beyond this openness, SAP is leveraging innovative technologies like AWS's ARM-based Graviton processors. Today, we are excited to announce the evolution of that partnership:

SAP and AWS will collaborate to bring the SAP BTP ABAP environment to Arm-based AWS Graviton processors.

 

A Longstanding History of Co-Innovation in the Cloud

Since 2008, SAP partnered with AWS to help customers leverage cloud innovations. In 2023, we announced that SAP HANA Cloud runs on AWS Graviton, a custom-built chip by AWS that delivers price, performance, and energy efficiency benefits for cloud workloads. By initially migrating SAP HANA Cloud to AWS Graviton3-based Amazon EC2 instances, SAP has seen up to 30% better compute performance for analytical workloads and lowered its compute carbon footprint by an estimated 45%. Building on these experiences, SAP and AWS have been continuously innovating to further improve the performance of SAP HANA Cloud.

Driving Flexibility and Performance

SAP BTP ABAP environment is the platform as a service offering for ABAP developers. It’s a cloud-optimized ABAP platform based on SAP HANA Cloud that serves as a development and runtime environment for cloud applications.

Initial tests have shown positive results for ABAP on AWS Graviton architectures, demonstrating strong performance and efficiency gains. With the extensive breadth of Amazon EC2 instance families available on Arm, SAP will be able to select the right instance type and size optimized for ABAP workloads and leverage this diverse portfolio for maximum instance flexibility for our customers.

Why Arm and AWS Graviton?

With AWS Graviton3-based instances, SAP experienced up to 35% price-performance improvement for analytics workloads, and a reduction of the compute carbon footprint of SAP HANA Cloud workloads. With AWS Graviton4-based instances, we’ve seen an up to 25% additional performance improvement for analytical and up to 40% additional improvement for transactional workloads compared to AWS Graviton3-based instances.

Now, with the next AWS Graviton5-based Amazon EC2 M9g instances, we’ve observed a 35-60% increase in the performance of our OLTP queries on SAP HANA Cloud in a single generation. Based on the performance improvements demonstrated in SAP HANA Cloud with AWS Graviton processors, SAP is confident the SAP BTP ABAP environment will also leverage AWS Graviton technology to deliver similar benefits.

A Strategic Partnership for Sustainability

This new collaboration continues our shared commitment to sustainability. SAP is a signatory of Amazon’s Climate Pledge and has accelerated its own sustainability commitment to 2030. Our journey with AWS Graviton aligns perfectly with those goals, and we are eager to see what additional improvements in energy efficiency we can realize together in the future.

What’s Next?

Porting the SAP BTP ABAP environment to AWS Graviton involves adapting its cloud-native architecture, including containerized services and runtime components, to Arm. SAP and AWS teams will continue developing, testing, and working on performance optimization pipelines to ensure a seamless experience for customers.

We look forward to sharing more updates on this project and the value it brings in terms of performance, reliability, and sustainability. Stay tuned as we continue this journey together.

entry.title: SAP Joule Studio 概况介绍
entry.content:
如果您对BTP感兴趣，BTP个人精选内容目录 | SAP Blogs 可能有更多你需要的内容

 

想象一下，明天早上你走进办公室，只需要对AI助手说一句话，就能自动查询库存、创建采购申请、分析现金流风险，甚至处理你们公司独特的业务流程。这不是科幻，而是SAP Joule Studio让每家企业都能实现的现实。

无论你是IT管理者还是业务用户，这个低代码平台都能帮你打造专属的AI工作助手，让重复繁琐的工作彻底自动化，释放时间去做更有价值的事情。

 

Joule Studio是什么？

定义： SAP Joule Studio是一个低代码开发平台，用于扩展Joule焦耳的功能

 

SAP为什么要开发SAP Joule Studio？

1.标准的Joule很难完全满足企业独特需求

2.Joule需要对接非SAP系统的流程与数据，才能实现端到端的AI智能化,而标准Joule在这方面功能的缺口更大

 

SAP Joule Studio的核心能力有哪些？

SAP将Joule需要的额外能力划分为两种：Skill和Agent

Joule在确认用户的意图之后，会思考如何回复，思考时就会自行判断是否需要Skill和Agent来帮忙

 

Skill：

可以理解为一条固定的工作流，Skill接收固定格式输入，执行确定任务，返回标准格式结果。

 

一般Skill用于提供数据查询以及操作执行的能力，例如通过API来调用接口，创建销售订单的Skill；亦或者调用数据库接口来查询数据的Skill

Joule调用Skill的示例流程：

  • 用户提问： "帮我查看产品A的库存，如果低于安全库存就自动创建采购申请"
  • 意图识别： Joule理解用户的意图，并判断需要进行主数据查询，库存查询，且后续可能需要执行库存补货动作
  • 能力匹配： Joule在可用Skill库中搜索，发现有可用的主数据查询Skill，库存查询Skill，库存补货Skill
  • 执行查询： Joule执行主数据查询Skill，确认物料编码，然后执行库存查询Skill，获取库存信息
  • 回答用户： Joule回复用户："产品A的主数据为XX，该产品库存为XX，已经低于安全库存XX，需要创建采购申请来补充库存吗？推荐补充XX数量的库存"

标准Joule已经原生具备了很多Skill，但用户可以开发更多Skill以丰富Joule的能力

 

Agent：

可以理解为专家咨询服务。Agent启动时需要的信息,工作流程，工作结束返回的信息都是不确定的。

但这些Agent比Joule更擅长完成特定类型的任务，例如应收账款专家Agent，售后服务专家Agent，一般由Joule自主决定何时调用哪个Agent来满足用户需求

具体的Agent列表可以在这里查看：https://discovery-center.cloud.sap/ai-catalog/?aiType=ai_agent

Joule调用Agent的示例流程：

  • 用户提问： "我们Q3的现金流状况如何？有什么风险需要注意？"
  • 意图识别： Joule理解用户的意图，并判断这是复杂的财务分析咨询请求，需要专业答复
  • 能力匹配： Joule在可用Agent库中找到"现金流专家Agent"，评估其能力与用户意图的匹配度
  • 执行查询： Joule将用户的问题和相关对话历史转交给财务分析Agent
  • 等待处理： Agent自主调用Skill，完成数据收集、分析计算、风险评估等工作，并答复Joule
  • 回答用户： Joule将Agent的专业分析转达给用户

标准Joule已经原生具备了很多Agent，但用户可以开发更多Skill以丰富Joule的能力，同时还可以定制化Joule的原生Agent

 

基于以上两种需求，Joule Studio提供两类工具：

  • Skill开发工具，可以低代码的创建Skill
  • Agent开发工具，可以低代码的创建新Agent，也可以增强SAP的标准Agent

以解决标准Joule无法满足的企业个性化需求，例如：

1. 补齐在SAP生态中标准Joule还不具备的能力

2. 为Joule对接SAP生态外的应用、数据、Agent，包括但不限于

  • 第三方系统集成：连接CRM、电商平台、IoT设备等外部系统的流程
  • 外部数据源整合：接入市场数据、天气信息、汇率数据等
  • 跨平台Agent协作：调用外部AI服务或专业分析工具

 

SAP Joule Studio和市面上常见的类似功能有什么区别？

Joule预置了大量Skill和Agent，代表了SAP理解的最佳实践，大大节约了用户的开发成本

Joule专门为SAP生态系统而设计，与SAP权限，流程，数据无缝集成，所以Joule Studio开发出的额外能力也天然适配SAP系统

 

SAP Joule Studio一般怎么用呢？

阶段一：需求识别与评估

通过系统化的流程分析识别当前痛点，卡点

通过用户日常使用Joule的反馈识别功能空白点

评估哪些需求适合用Skill解决，哪些需要Agent处理

阶段二：选择开发方式

Skill开发适用于：

  • 标准化的数据查询操作
  • 固定流程的业务处理
  • 简单的API调用和数据转换
  • 需要快速响应的操作

Agent开发适用于：

  • 需要专业判断的复杂分析
  • 多步骤的决策流程
  • 个性化的咨询服务
  • 需要上下文理解的对话

阶段三：开发与部署

阶段四：持续优化

  • 监控Skill和Agent的使用频率和成功率
  • 基于用户反馈不断完善功能
  • 根据业务变化调整配置参数
  • 扩展更多相关的能力组合

 

总结

SAP Joule Studio提供定制化AI开发能力，以扩展Joule功能以解决定制化需求，实现AI自动化和效率提升
